title: 111_hr1999
content: The Act is titled the "Temporary Recession Aid for Schools and Taxpayers Act" and authorizes grants to local governments. The "Temporary Recession Aid for Schools and Taxpayers Act" authorizes grants to eligible local governments for elementary and secondary school education programs based on property tax revenue decreases. Grants are awarded for a maximum of 3 years. The grant amounts awarded to eligible local governments under the "Temporary Recession Aid for Schools and Taxpayers Act" are limited to a maximum of $40,000,000 over a 3-year period. The grant amount decreases each year, starting at 70% of the property tax revenue difference in the first year, then 50% in the second year, and 25% in the third year. Application requirements must be met to qualify for the grant. To qualify for a grant under the "Temporary Recession Aid for Schools and Taxpayers Act," eligible local governments must submit an application within 2 months after the end of fiscal year 2009 or 2010. The application should include the decrease in property tax revenues from the previous fiscal year and plans for operating without the grant funds after the 3-year period. Priority in grant awards is given to local governments by the Secretary of Education. Education shall prioritize eligible local governments that have experienced significant decreases in property tax revenues due to the closure of large or multiple small employers. Grant funds must be used for specific purposes as outlined in the Act. Grant funds under this Act are designated for elementary and secondary school education programs, including construction, teacher salaries, and school nutrition programs funded by eligible local governments. $100,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2013. Eligible local governments must have the authority to levy property taxes and have experienced a 15% decrease in revenue. Local governments eligible for grant funds must have experienced a 15% decrease in property tax revenues from fiscal year 2008 to 2010 or from fiscal year 2009 to 2010. The funds must be spent on elementary and secondary education programs within the jurisdiction of the local government. The term "fiscal year" refers to the applicable State or local law definition. "Property tax revenues" are generated by levying real property taxes based on property value within the local government's jurisdiction. The term "State" refers to each of the 50 States. The term "State" refers to each of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. The term "tax base" refers to the assessment by a local government of the total value of taxable real property within its jurisdiction. The Act will be effective by November 1, 2009.
